publicwhip.spmotion: *S3M-2244 Bill Kidd: Congratulations to Glasgow City Council—That the Parliament congratulates Glasgow City Council on its findings that 72% of Glaswegians would be better off under local income tax as opposed to the unfair council tax, and believes that, given the persistent high levels of multiple deprivation in Glasgow under successive UK Governments, the introduction of a local income tax would contribute substantially to combating poverty in Glasgow and consequently would also combat poverty in all other areas of Scotland, both urban and rural, experiencing high levels of poverty. R

S3M-2244 Congratulations to Glasgow City Council (lodged on 23 June 2008) Jamie Hepburn*, Christina McKelvie*, Rob Gibson*, Kenneth Gibson*, Aileen Campbell*, Bill Wilson*, Alasdair Allan*, Alex Neil*, Bob Doris*, Bashir Ahmad*, Brian Adam*
S3M-2244 Congratulations to Glasgow City Council (lodged on 23 June 2008) Christine Grahame*, Stuart McMillan*, Gil Paterson*
S3M-2244 Congratulations to Glasgow City Council (lodged on 23 June 2008) Joe FitzPatrick*

S3M-2244 Bill Kidd: Congratulations to Glasgow City Council—That the Parliament congratulates Glasgow City Council on its findings that 72% of Glaswegians would be better off under local income tax as opposed to the unfair council tax, and believes that, given the persistent high levels of multiple deprivation in Glasgow under successive UK Governments, the introduction of a local income tax would contribute substantially to combating poverty in Glasgow and consequently would also combat poverty in all other areas of Scotland, both urban and rural, experiencing high levels of poverty. R Supported by: Jamie Hepburn, Christina McKelvie, Rob Gibson, Kenneth Gibson, Aileen Campbell, Bill Wilson, Alasdair Allan, Alex Neil, Bob Doris, Bashir Ahmad, Brian Adam, Christine Grahame, Stuart McMillan, Gil Paterson, Joe FitzPatrick, Michael Matheson*

*S3M-2244 Bill Kidd: Congratulations to Glasgow City Council—That the Parliament congratulates Glasgow City Council on its findings that 72% of Glaswegians would be better off under local income tax as opposed to the unfair council tax, and believes that, given the persistent high levels of multiple deprivation in Glasgow under successive UK Governments, the introduction of a local income tax would contribute substantially to combating poverty in Glasgow and consequently would also combat poverty in all other areas of Scotland, both urban and rural, experiencing high levels of poverty. R Supported by: Jamie Hepburn, Christina McKelvie, Rob Gibson, Kenneth Gibson, Aileen Campbell, Bill Wilson, Alasdair Allan, Alex Neil, Bob Doris, Bashir Ahmad, Brian Adam, Christine Grahame, Stuart McMillan, Gil Paterson, Joe FitzPatrick, Michael Matheson
